content: The Act may be cited as the "Human Rights Information Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of human rights and the rule of law, as enshrined in the Constitution. Federal agencies possess documents on human rights violations abroad that are crucial for foreign authorities to investigate and prosecute. The United States prioritizes and protects human rights in the Constitution. Federal agencies hold documents on gross human rights violations abroad needed by foreign authorities for investigation and prosecution. Requests for legal assistance on human rights violations, including document declassification, are received from foreign authorities. The United States receives requests from foreign authorities for legal assistance on human rights violations, including document declassification. Recently, a Spanish court magistrate requested information on General Augusto Pinochet from the United States. The United States receives requests for information on human rights violations from foreign authorities, including a recent request from a Spanish court magistrate regarding General Augusto Pinochet. The US follows specific procedures for declassification requests outlined in Presidential directives and executive orders to protect and promote human rights nationally and internationally. Strengthening existing declassification procedures, including the Freedom of Information Act, is crucial to meet the US's commitment to human rights. The United States is committed to protecting and promoting human rights nationally and internationally. Strengthening declassification procedures, including the Freedom of Information Act, is essential for the expedient declassification of human rights documents to protect global human rights and strengthen the rule of law internationally. The expedient declassification of human rights documents in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act will protect global human rights, strengthen the rule of law internationally, and increase accountability of Federal agencies, leading to significant savings of Government resources. The United States' commitment to promoting human rights and democracy globally has resulted in diplomatic, economic, and military efforts. The United States' commitment to promoting human rights globally has led to diplomatic, economic, and military efforts to end human rights violations abroad. Numerous US NGOs and citizens also advocate for human rights. The United States promotes human rights globally through diplomatic, economic, and military efforts. US NGOs and citizens also advocate for human rights in foreign countries, but these efforts are hindered if impunity for human rights violations persists. This could lead to the need for renewed US engagements in those areas. The United States has a significant interest in newly established democratic societies addressing human rights violations through credible investigations and prosecutions, which may involve truth commissions, human rights officers, or tribunals. The United States emphasizes the importance of newly established democratic societies conducting credible investigations and prosecutions for human rights violations. This can involve truth commissions, human rights officers, or national investigations led by civil society organizations. The US has historically led efforts to end impunity for gross human rights violations and promote the rule of law globally. The United States has provided international leadership to end impunity for human rights violations by supporting various war crimes tribunals and ratifying the Convention against Torture. The United States has ratified the Convention against Torture and actively participated in various international war crimes tribunals. The United States, as a member State of the Organization of American States, is obligated to provide assistance in criminal proceedings related to torture acts and comply with recommendations for free access to evidence. The United States, as an Organization of American States member, should adopt measures for free access to information in criminal investigations, as recommended by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. The Guatemalan peace accords, supported by the United States, included an investigation by the Clarification Commission to establish criminal responsibility for international crimes and human rights violations. Despite the investigation's conclusion, the importance of access to information in criminal investigations is emphasized by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. The Clarification Commission's investigation into human rights violations in Guatemala left many unanswered questions, including the identities of perpetrators and the whereabouts of the disappeared. Legal and material resources were recommended to be utilized for further investigation. The Clarification Commission recommended utilizing all resources to clarify the whereabouts of the disappeared and deliver remains to relatives. A parallel investigation called "Guatemala: Never Again" was presented two days later by the Historical Memory Recovery Project. Two days after presenting a parallel investigation, "Guatemala: Never Again", Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, director of the Historical Memory Recovery Project, was assassinated. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting action. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting documentation from the United States on human rights violations since 1993. Some aspects of the request have been fulfilled, but others are still pending. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "human rights record" refers to information on gross violations of human rights post-1944 held by the US Government. "Agency" includes entities like the Department of State, Agency for International Development, Department of Defense, Central Intelligence Agency, and National. The United States Government agencies responsible for foreign policy and intelligence include the Department of State, Agency for International Development, Department of Defense, Central Intelligence Agency, National Reconnaissance Office, Department of Justice, National Security Council, and Executive Office of the President. Gross violations of internationally recognized human rights are defined in the Act. The term "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" is defined in the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION, REVIEW, AND PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS REGARDING GUATEMALA AND HONDURAS. The Act governs the declassification and public disclosure of human rights records by agencies. Each agency must identify, review, and organize human rights records related to Guatemala and Honduras after 1944 for declassification. Records must be made public within 30 days after review completion. The Act requires agencies to organize human rights records from Guatemala and Honduras post-1944 for declassification and public disclosure within 30 days. The President must report to Congress on agency compliance within 150 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. GROUNDS FOR POSTPONEMENT OF PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF RECORDS. An agency may delay public disclosure of a human rights record if there is clear evidence that the threat to national security outweighs the public interest, such as revealing intelligence agents or sources. States can delay public disclosure of human rights records if the threat to national security outweighs the public interest, especially if it involves revealing intelligence agents or sources. The disclosure of information related to military defense, intelligence operations, or foreign relations of the United States may be delayed if it would interfere with intelligence activities or impair national security. The public disclosure of human rights records may endanger individuals who provided confidential information to the United States. The public disclosure of human rights records may endanger individuals who provided confidential information to the United States, posing a substantial risk of harm. This risk justifies withholding the information to protect national security and personal privacy. The public disclosure of human rights records could pose a substantial risk of harm to individuals, constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, or compromise confidentiality agreements, outweighing the public interest. The public disclosure of human rights records may be postponed if it compromises confidentiality agreements between a Government agent and a cooperating individual or foreign government, outweighing the public interest. It is not grounds for postponement that an individual named in the record was an intelligence asset of the United States Government. The disclosure of human rights records can be postponed if it compromises confidentiality agreements, but not solely because an individual named was a US intelligence asset. The term "intelligence asset" refers to a covert agent as defined in the National Security Act of 1947. When requested by international entities or national commissions investigating human rights violations, US agencies must review and disclose relevant records following specified standards and procedures. SEC. 7. REVIEW OF DECISIONS TO WITHHOLD RECORDS. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions to postpone public disclosure of human rights records and directs disclosure unless there is clear evidence otherwise. The Appeals Panel directs disclosure of all human rights records unless clear evidence shows otherwise, allowing for postponement in certain cases. The Appeals Panel may postpone disclosure of a human rights record if it qualifies under section 5, and will determine alternative forms of disclosure in consultation with the agency. The Appeals Panel, in consultation with the agency, will determine alternative forms of disclosure for a human rights record, such as disclosing a reasonably segregable portion after deletion of certain parts or providing a substitute record for undisclosed information. The Appeals Panel, in consultation with the agency, will determine alternative forms of disclosure for a human rights record, such as disclosing a reasonably segregable portion after deletion of certain parts, providing a substitute record, or a summary of the information. Upon completion of its review, the Appeals Panel notifies the agency head. The Appeals Panel will disclose a summary of the information in the human rights record and notify the agency head of its determination within 14 days, publishing it in the Federal Register. The Appeals Panel will notify the President of its determination on the human rights record within 14 days, providing a written justification for its decision. The determination will be published in the Federal Register. The Appeals Panel will notify the President of its determination with a written justification, including an explanation of the standards applied. The President has the authority to review any determination and decide on public disclosure. The President has the sole authority to review and make a decision on the Appeals Panel's determination within 30 days, based on set standards. The President must provide the Appeals Panel with a written certification within 30 days of their determination, stating the decision and reasons, including if disclosure is postponed based on set standards. The President's decision and reasons for postponing disclosure of a human rights record must be provided to the Appeals Panel within 30 days, along with any relevant materials published in the Federal Register. The Information Security Policy Advisory Council will report to Congress on the declassification of human rights records for other countries. The report will be made public. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit the right to file a request with an executive agency or seek judicial review under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. Judicial review is not precluded under chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code for final actions taken under this Act. SEC. 10. CREATION OF POSITIONS. SEC. 10. CREATION OF POSITIONS. Two additional positions in the Appeals Panel will be created for individuals with substantial human rights expertise appointed by the President. Recommendations for these positions will be sought from nongovernmental human rights organizations.
